RT @KarlTheMartian: @meliss_hughes this is the lasting, invisible damage. Greater cultural awareness of this could help so, so many people.
Pls be aware: there is serious abuse that leaves no physical marks & is legal. & the only evidence we have is that fragile sense of reality.
So, when a woman has the guts to say she was abused, know that in the vast majority, it doesn't come lightly. Believe her.
That's the thing. With certain kinds of abuse, it can be hard enough to believe yourself, never mind asking others to believe you.
I even went crawling back, trying to make nice, to have a friendly resolution, thinking "it was all in my head."
I realized later he'd begun a process of gaslighting me; playing with my sense of reality so I'd question myself.
But my brain told me, no, this can't have happened. No one is that awful. No one *plans* to hurt someone else. You must have misunderstood.
It was real. I felt as if I'd been kicked. I was unable to sleep in my own bed. I couldn't get clean no matter how I scrubbed. For a reason.
If the abuse was emotional, you may find yourself questioning yourself (I did). "Is this real? Did this really happen to me?"
This is part of the damage abusers inflict; you maybe just don't want to talk or think about it. You maybe just want it to go away.
Kilgrave sounds like someone I know, well. Worried it will be too triggering.

IF I'm feeling up to being vulnerable. Bit of a diff way to use Twitter, & maybe odd/annoying to some, but that's ok. Takes all kinds ‚ù§Ô∏è
By which I mean that when I'm having feelings (always, lol) if I think it's possibly relevant / helpful to others, I sometimes tweet it.
I know my TL can be a little intense at times, & isn't everyone's cup of tea. I sometimes do things a little differently...
Clarification: When I tweet introspectively, I'm not upset or seeking help. I appreciate concern, but when upset I reach out to friends ‚ù§Ô∏è
@bovermyer I'm actually quite well. I often tweet introspectively / into deeper emotional territory. Sorry to hear things are rough.
It's an internalized belief, one that defies reason, one I need to shout down until it recedes. Sensitive does not = weak. Repeat.
Truth is, I'm ashamed of how sensitive I am. How deeply I feel things that some others might barely flinch at. I believe they are superior.
@bovermyer I'm sorry. I hope what I said didn't make it worse.
In my case: I always wish I hadn't shown weakness, usually with men. Wish I hadn't cried in front of someone or showed how much I care.
Until you forgive yourself, or learn to frame memories differently, the past will continue to haunt you.

@MullerDerrick I can't answer that for you. My observation: it does seem courage  and feeling alone go together at times.
If you've chosen being single over relationships that are damaging, or 'less than,' hold your head up high. You are BRAVE and POWERFUL.
KNOW that when you opt out of this system & relationships that devalue you, you are not losing out: you are taking back your POWER.
REFUSE TO GO ALONG with social norms that promote hatred of, and systemically devalue, women.
IGNORE the dating apps that reduce sexuality to a commodity and work in men's favour, nine times out of ten.
IGNORE the men who objectify you based on bullshit criteria they are largely excluded from.
IGNORE the mass media that tells you that you are the sum of your looks and your sexuality.
Your body, and your life, is for whatever purpose you decide. You get to call those shots. Don't let anyone tell you otherwise.
Women: please ignore the terrible life advice that is everywhere, telling us that our primary purpose is to please men.
